review_title: Chaotic With Office Politics Rivaling Game of Thrones
pros: Great Pay Good benefits You work with incredibly talented people You can really kickstart your career as long as you are loyal friends to managers.
cons: Constant restructures. Talented people get hired and leave within 2 years because their team doesn't get the support they need. Deeply political. Departments fight against each other. I was encouraged to hide work I was doing from the department I technically worked for because it made my current department look bad. Management promoted close friends. Corporate structure made it easier to hide incompetence. There were no systems of accountability. When leaders realized moral was really bad, it came as whiplash. The reality was that these problems had been there for awhile but because of the above factors, there was no incentive or reward for sharing critical feedback.

cons: Management is always asking for more, and willing to give nothing. The organization is always trying to expand, but does not set up employees with the proper staff, pay or training to meet those demands. My personal supervisor tends to delegate various responsibilities, in the name of our specific program, but does not follow through on the same obligations herself. Additionally, it seems as if there is no room for advancement in program coordination.

review_title: Short sided Leadership and High Turnover
pros: The mission is important and critical to the future of young people everywhere. Flexibility to work remotely in certain instances or flexible schedule for in office days. Opportunities to move up are there but limited. Great colleagues outside of Senior Leadership
cons: Senior Leadership is toxic and short sighted. Frequently enforcing deadlines that can’t be met due to their poor planning. Senior Leaders and Senior Managers are encouraged to back stab each other and this bleeds into other departments not trusting each other. The Development Department regularly misleads funders for their own benefit and to the detriment of other programs and departments. The senior leaders in Development frequently steam rolled projects to ensure they received the most funding and Clubs were given small pieces of what was left over. Forget any sort of collaborative effort here. It is truly every man out for themselves. This is not a team effort. If you spoke up in this culture, you’re met with loads of excuses and gaslighting from management as well as their CDO and NVPs. The CEO is incredibly ineffective. His lack of leadership skills and poor management causes absolutely chaos in all departments. He encourages and rewards bad behavior with senior leadership. I’d never recommend a trusted friend or colleague to work at this place. It’s a black hole where ideas and souls go to die.

job_title: School Site Coordinator in Reno, NV
pros: The members are the best part, you get to know them really quickly and bond with them. You make lasting memories and grow a set of skills in teaching and managing massive groups of them.
cons:
Management
I have no idea where to start... There is so much internal movement within the club that is impossible to predict the next move. It's not like they purposely leave you out of things, it just happens due to the amount of turmoil that exists. You get to know one guy and before you know it, they end up moving to another part of the organization before you even get a second to think about what just happened. There is no control, no order and its a shame. 

Salary 
When you sign up to be a coordinator, you are told that it is full-time. That is not true as the average workweek that someone will work in this position is around 33 hours, it may hit 40 if there is extra training or meetings happening but for the most part that's it. During the break, it becomes full-time, but just barely.

Training 
There is no training, very little at best. It's all spread out and they happen at least once a month in a massive setting. You are supposed to have a week's worth of training before you are given a site, but that never happened to me. As such, I was left on my own to figure things out meanwhile there are six other members getting in a fight or clogging the toilet with chicken nuggets. 

Cliquish
Outsiders are not really all that welcomed in my experience... Especially if you have little to no experience working with kiddos. There's a massive amount of jargon that you are expected to just know off the bat, and this all ties back to the lack of training.

job_title: Youth Development Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The relationships you build with the kids.
cons:
Lack of support, favoritism, pay isn’t enough, feels like they don’t care.


The programs they ask you to enforce on these kids who have already been at school all day is ridiculous. The kids want to have fun, they don’t want to feel like they are still at school. The kids only went outside a handful of times while I worked there, and when staff asked if the kids could go outside, we were met with a “No”, even on days when we would be open from 7am-6pm, they wouldn’t let them go outside. There was a lot of divide within staff and management, often felt like sides were being picked. It was noticeable that there were favorites amongst staff with the program director, and often felt like the staff they didn’t like was picked on. When things were brought to higher ups attention, nothing would be done. There was absolutely no discipline in the place for the kids. They got away with being disrespectful to the staff and the bullying amongst the kids was extremely out of hand. Once again, both things were brought to management’s attention and nothing was done. It often felt like we weren’t heard about our concerns that impact the kids the most or frankly, that they didn’t care. YDS are part time employees and the countless of times we brought home work to plan things for the kids were unacceptable. When brought to their attention, we were told we could come in earlier, however when the time came to do so it never felt like we actually could. We were also told that if we needed supplies to put it on the supply list and they would provide it for us, despite putting supplies on the list there was only 1 or 2 times we actually got the supplies we needed. Most of the time our own money was spent on buying supplies for the kids. The lack of support from management with the kids and facilitating programs was evidently the reason why I left. It felt more so about the money and less about the kids.

pros: As far as childcare jobs go, BGC can be pretty good. It really depends on the location but generally it’s on the same standard as working at a YMCA or similar place. The staff really try their best and it’s easy to become attached to the kids. If you’re looking for a part-time job working in childcare, this is about as good as it gets in the U.S.
cons:
Monthly staff training sessions and extra training units for Site Directors just doesn’t make up for the fact that the staff are unqualified for the work. Because the job is part-time with rock bottom pay and no benefits whatsoever, it is impossible to employ people with actual qualifications or to keep staff long enough that they can learn through experience. Running an after-school program is the type of job a person ought to be able to do as a career but as it is BGC will only ever have a revolving door of young, unqualified, direly underpaid staff.

I also found that a lot of management policies and training content was completely disconnected from the reality of the students. I’m sure things are very different depending on where you are, but my location required us to do so many extra lessons that after-school club turned into an extra 2 hours of school. Kids already spend 8 hours a day being yelled at by school staff with hardly any break (at the school I worked at they only got a couple 15-minute recesses in the whole school day!) - what they need after school is leisure time for rest, fun, and socialization. They need the chance to exercise their autonomy which they don’t get during the school day. But the management at my location seemed convinced that students are little robots you can shovel programming into all day long. You wouldn’t expect an adult to sit quietly through 10 straight hours of schooling so why do we expect kids to?

pros: The kids were so much fun, I had the ability to be creative and a big kid again. Very rewarding in the sense that you see your impact daily, the kids love you so much as did we!
cons:
Management. 

As of 2019, we had a new CEO come in, Calvin Lyons, he completely changed our club culture for the worse and appointed individuals who do not know how to work or communicate with staff to higher management. I constantly felt belittled by this individual, interrogated, and was often left with no support. I was sad by what was happening as soon as this individual became my "manager". There was a lack of empathy from him and honestly, he treated everyone like they didn't exist. He would never acknowledge you with a "good morning" and never said "hi".  

I reported this to the Board and they did nothing about it, I was told by the president, to "not take my job so seriously" in an all-staff meeting...how helpful. I felt helpless and like no one cared. It was disappointing because I really loved our club and the kids who came to it. 

Please do not choose to work here, they will cut you off quickly, give you terrible pay and work you until the bone. The Board does not care about you nor does anyone in upper management. Calvin never took the time to get to know us as a staff, or individually. Unfortunately, the kids suffer as a result.

job_title: Summer Camp Counselor in Wilmington, DE
pros: Some of the best reasons to work for this company is that it's very satisfying when you're working with the children, being that they are typically low income and they need your support. I took a job as a summer camp counselor and was given a rather large group of 5-6 year olds. The previous year I worked for another summer camp, but that was with a different demographic of children. I thought the Boy and Girls Clubs was better because there was a set, 9 to 5 schedule that was 24 hours like I had to do previously.
cons: Well, there were plenty of things I didn't like. While I was paid decently, I had to deal with lazy coworkers who treated me badly after finding out how that I was paid more (I had more education and experience). The place was extremely disorganized. Every single day we were given a new schedule. I kid you not. There was poor communication between management and subordinates and also among coworkers. There was also unfair, inconsistent treatment that involved politics. Many of the kids were tough to deal with and had behavioral problems, but sadly that was probably one of the best things about working there. I wouldn't recommend this job to my worst enemy.

review_title: It's not a job for everybody
pros: Most the kids are really great and helpful! You will see how you impact many of them and the job is really rewarding in that way! The coworkers at my location were also great for the most part - if you get along with people easily you should be fine!
cons: Some of the kids go through some tough things at home, and it can be really heavy sometimes, and also often results in them acting out at the club. There was also a bit of favoritism/nepotism between the staff and directors which can be frustrating.  A few staff are allowed to get away with anything while not working, and at a place that is often understaffed, it is really important that everybody is giving it their all. At locations like this, expect a heavy workload and lots of stress while you pick up other people's slack. It is one of those jobs where a lot of children rely on you to be responsible as an adult, and someone has to be that person if other people will not be. When not everybody is helping out, there is more potential for injuries and incidents, which then make you look bad as a staff. It can be a frustrating cycle, but if you have good staff in your room with you, it is great!

review_title: Worthy community investment which can be very emotionally demanding.
pros:
The investing that Boys and Girls Clubs do in the community is important and beneficial but also can be overwhelming in its magnitude.  The outreach to the Latino community in Atlanta was important and I believe we firmly made a difference in many of the kids lives which was the real point of all of our work. 
There was also a good sense of togetherness among the Club staff during my time there.  Our staff was pretty unified and very diverse which helped us deal with a myriad of issues.  
Kids were in extreme need of support, mentoring, and direction which was extremely satisfying and very emotionally rewarding.
It is a non-profit enterprise which afford good purpose toward the kids.
cons:
The overall pay was somewhat low relative to the market.  However, there is not much of a market for this type of work.  The part time work is important but only part time.  There was also no benefits.  Emotionally is can be extremely overwhelming when you find out about some of the situations that the kids are in or things they get involved with.
Some kids are very poorly behaved and with serious obedience and authority issues.
There can be limited to no support among parents for their kids' behavior.  However, some parents are better than others.
Most middle and upper management are more interested in hob-nobbing with athletes than really making a difference.
A non profit enterprise.

review_title: Fantastic Mission without the Infrastructure to Support It.
pros: Working with economically disadvantaged youth, working with this organization can be incredibly rewarding.  The members and families truly need and benefit from the services provided.  The mission of the organization is toward healthy lifestyles, academic success, and good character and citizenship.  It is meaningful work.
cons:
The administration sacrifices its employees for the mission.  Routinely paying $7 an hour to new employees, even seasoned employees (10+ years) make between $35 - 40k.  Top BGCTNV administration are paid 60k - 80k but many are disconnected from day-to-day employees.  

The benefits are some of the lowest in the non-profit sector.  Moving up in the company takes years, they do not compensate responsibility with salary, and moving employees at-will is common.  Furthermore, the administration expects employees to work long hours with almost no autonomy. Every club is understaffed, so much so that all full-time employees are now required to drive a school bus or risk being fired.  These facets lead to an air of cynicism and pessimism from long-term employees and creates a toxic environment for the organization.

The administration is unfortunately too consumed with the capital campaign of raising funds and proving numbers by bringing in more youth and not concerned enough about the lasting infrastructure of the company and happiness or wellbeing of their employees.

review_title: Middle Management - Love the job but nowhere to grow!
job_title: Director, Program Management in Boston, MA
pros:
Staff love what they do, working with kids is extremely rewarding. 
Pay far exceeds what is available from other non profits, I used to work for the Y and the Club pays $10k more for the same job.
Lots of resources to create great programs and a large network of alum and supporters.

Great benefits including days off for snow days (great in New England) , 3 weeks vacation as well as sick days. Also an additional paid week off between Christmas and New year.

Fantastic comeraderie and coming to work is like a family.
cons:
The Club is full of “veterans” who have been at the same club for decades, especially at the Club director and and middle management level. This makes it hard to move up as spots are never vacant!! This was hard coming from the Y where the culture was very much to “keep moving, keep growing”. Unfortunately this means many talented younger people seek progression elsewhere when they outgrow their position.

This is also means that many clubs are resistant to new ideas and processes as “this has always worked here and we’ve been doing it for decades”. Not always the case, but much harder to bring in new ideas than anywhere else I’ve worked.

review_title: Occasionally overwhelmed, but the kids are worth it
pros: Besides being a huge part of kids lives, as an employee you are treated with respect and courtesy, and supervisors work with you to make sure you have everything you need. You are also treated as if you are important, and reminded you are important, which is a great way to retain employees.
cons:
There aren't many cons, but if I were to list an important one, it would have to be staffing. Some clubs are understaffed, making it difficult for employees who need vacation and time off or even sick days. 

Another con that although isn't important but creates minor grievances: there is no employee store for acquiring boys and girl club apparel. Although for the most part you are usually working in a relaxed environment, it creates a nice image for parents and kids alike when they see employees/counselors wearing boys and girls club attire. The only times we can get attire are freebies from corporate or when ordering shirts for the kids for summer. this presents an issue when it is cold out and you have to wear layers.

You have a hand at shaping the future. 
Great coworkers 
Learn how to deal with children from all walks of life

cons:

Salaried employees are expected to give up their weekends at a blink of an eye without hesitation. Again, not how good companies run. Leadership always talks about accountability, but in business we learn most people that preach about accountability, are not accountable themselves and do not stick to company policies.

review_title: Great to give back to the community and kids.
pros:
As a former Club Kid, it was great to find a job while in college that could be flexible around my schedule. While working in the games room, I found that this job is much more than shooting hoops with the youth, its about a lasting impact. After speaking with my Program Director at the time about career opportunities, I quickly changed my major and pursued a Club Career. I was able to move from Teen Coordinator, to Program Director, to running my own Club now as a Unit/Club Director. It really has been an amazing journey to give back to the organization that kept me out of trouble as a kid, and taught me valuable skills and lessons.

I would recommend this job and company for anyone who has a passion for making a difference.
cons: I share with my family and friends that this is a job of passion. Few get "rich" by working with the Clubs. I see CPOs and Executive Directors making up to $90,000 a year, but realistically those jobs are few and far between with most in my opinion being filled by non-Club people. They usually have a finance or business background, which is great to have, but for the the Club-level staff there is a income, and postion ceiling for sure.

pros: The staff is really organized and efficient, you will always know your hours weeks ahead of time and what activities your'll be doing. There are also staff meetings to make sure everyone has the same goals and objectives. There is alot of hands on interaction with the kids that you can choose to make the best out of. Children are so entertaining when you sit down and talk to them. There is a strong sense of community so after a while you will start to feel like you're a community staple yourself, which is great because you never know what kind of connections you could be making. Become a kid's hero and their mom just might offer you a job, happened for me.
cons: You have to have an assertive but tender personality. For safety and health reasons the children have to respect your authority and listen. But if they're scared of you they won't want to come and parents will be upset. It takes the right personality. Spending alot of time with kids can aggravate you if you are not a children person. They are also really stingy raises and definitely promotions. It's a great stepping stool into other jobs though.

pros: Helps children have a better and more successful life.
cons: I don’t remember being this disappointed ever.  I’ve been crying for two days.  The organization I worked for, Boys & Girls Clubs of America in Atlanta, GA, have let me down so bad it hurts.  For seven years I gave not only of my talents, but also my heart and soul.  I have continued to support BGCA even after retiring in 2012.  My husband just retired and we need a statement from BGCA showing he was covered under my insurance so we can get our retirement insurance with Kaiser Permanente going.  My phone calls to HR have gone unanswered and my pleas for help via email are being bounced from one person to the next with nobody willing to take the time to help me.  In contrast, when my husband’s employer was notified we needed this information for me to be covered, we had a completed form within 4 hours.  I guess some companies look after their retirees and some don’t.  It hurts so bad that BGCA doesn’t care that Wayne could be without health insurance starting next month just because they can’t take the time to fill out a form.

cons: Management sucks, there’s a high turnover rate for a reason

review_title: Great Futures - IF you fit the profile
pros: From my experience, if you were male and a person of color, you were great at brown-nosing with a big smile on your face, and you could convincingly claim that "Boys & Girls Club saved my life" (whether that is true or not), you could advance your career and get lots of perks - like a company vehicle to drive (all expenses paid), bonus pay, Fridays off for golf with potential donors, and other days off that no one counts against your vacation time.
cons: If you were an educated, white, female, liberal do-gooder, they will be happy to let you work as hard as you can to make them look good - but don't expect your male colleagues to ever have to work as hard as you, definitely don't call them out on it, don't expect to be paid as much as them, don't expect Board members to refrain from making stupid sexist jokes in meetings, and don't expect that your years of service or your work will be valued - no matter how much value you actually had to the day to day operations of the organization.  And don't let the door hit ya where the dog shoulda bit ya.

pros: Met some great colleagues & associates that I still keep in contact with today. Good pay for a non-profit organization.
cons:
Old School business culture, with outdated processes, lots of manual processes & physical paper handling. Many of the Executive Managers are micro-managers and don't give their direct reports freedom to use their own minds to complete projects & tasks. Extremely under-staffed & most employees are doing the work of 2 or 3 people. The HR Senior Leaders are fake & do not look out for the best interest of employees. There is High-turnover and the company has a difficult time keeping good talent.

Unless you enjoy being micro-managed, over-worked, under-appreciated, working in a toxic environment, and having NO work-life balance, don't go work at Boys & Girls Clubs of America. I would not refer or recommend for anyone to go work here unless they are beginners to the working world. Experienced Professionals Beware!

pros: Ability to build relationships with kids and make positive difference
cons: My experience there was stressful and isolating. Working with the kids there was great and they really made me want to stay. However, what caused me to quit was the isolating and negative environment I felt from other coworkers there. I did not feel welcome or properly trained. This was disappointing because it seems to opposite of what the organization stands for. It seemed that behind the scenes, this was not the case. There was a very unprofessional and intimidating vibe from coworkers and very clique-ish. Trying to deal with this high-school like workplace environment makes it really hard to be your best with these kids. I hope this is not the case with all of their sites! I am not usually writing negative reviews, but this was something that clearly was a bad experience which caused me to doubt my own abilities. Pay attention to the way coworkers interact with you right from the start. If they are cold and downplay your leadership, please do not stick around like I did!

job_title: Assistant Unit Director in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: If you have a passion for working with children and teens, especially youth coming from difficult circumstances, you will really enjoy the opportunities for direct impact on youth in need of mentors.
cons: Most direct-care employers are intentionally overworked and underpaid. At my club, the staff who were most passionate and dedicated to working with youth were taken advantage of. Those who believed in the mission were paid the least and worked the most. It was a very disappointing work culture considering how valuable the program is for young people. I asked for higher pay when I improved the program and was denied. I could no longer pay my bills on the low salary so I turned in a two-weeks notice. It was only when I was resigning that my supervisor offered the pay I deserved, but I left anyway because the organization did not value my effort and dedication. I have heard similar stories from BGC employees in other regions of my state, and even from those in other states.

review_title: Actual BGCA rating: 2.7. Do yourself a favor and work anywhere else!
pros: Check out the sorting feature on Glassdoor - if you sort reviews by area, the rating plummets to 2.7 for Atlanta, which includes HQ. You can read through the reviews from there to see what people are saying about BGCA itself, not just clubs. Spoiler alert: it's not pretty. BGCA has an amazing mission of serving kids, which is unfortunately the only pro, and, for most of us, not enough to compensate for the toxic work environment and clear disregard for our well-being from senior management.
cons: You will not be trusted to do your job. You will not be given flexibility or autonomy. You will be micro-managed every step of the way. You will be managed by people who do not know how to do your job. You will be measured on whether you sat in your chair for the requisite number of hours rather than on whether you delivered on your goals. You will feel crazed and hectic because everything will be marked urgent,  you'll be bombarded by emails and meeting requests, and you'll have to find time to squeeze in your own chart of work in the midst of it. You might luck out and be on one of the few teams with managers who respect and trust their employees, but - I'm so sorry - you probably won't.

pros: It was an okay place to work
cons: Needs to make some improvements

review_title: You must value helping the kids above all else.
pros: You're able to make a huge impact on the kids in the community working here. It's really rewarding to be able to see the kids learn new skills and have a positive outlook for their future. You will easily get hired if you have a college bachelor's degree and have a friendly personality.
cons: The job you can get does not have to relate to your degree at all so some of your coworkers may be lacking skills for their job. The company is non-profit so the pay will be significantly lower than average for your job. That leads to the environment being very laid back and at times lazy because people think they don't have to work as hard because of the lower pay. You will work an average of 35-40 hours a week.

pros: It can be fun and you are able to love kids while doing your job.  I like being able to interact with so many different people.  We come in contact with people of different races and belief systems. Youth Enrichment accepts and cares about every child.
cons: I sometimes feel like a number to the company.  They have a tight budget so sometimes they will ask you to leave early if you are not needed (if your boss can fill in for you).  It really does depend on who the director of your site is.  I have had a total of five directors and out of them I have only had two that pushed me home really early or treated me like I was stupid.  The one I have now is amazing and actually cares about us.

review_title: BGCA -- and great place to work
pros: The satisfaction of knowing you are helping disadvantaged youth in every action you take every day.  Even for those of us who "work in the background" the results of our efforts are shown to us often with visits from club members, Youth of the Year presentations and celebrity visits.  Denzel Washington is frequently in attendance at BGCA functions, and Michael Phelps spent time with the national staff at our heardquarters a few weeks ago.  All in all it is a very rewarding place to work.
cons: Well, since it is a non-profit, salaries are not as competivie as those in the for profit sector.  BGCA has attempted to offset that by providing excellent benefits (including parking in downtown Atlanta) at no or low cost to employees.

review_title: Great experience, with making a difference in kid’s life as well as the community
job_title: Assistant Unit Director in Bentonville, AR
pros:
You feel good at the end of the day. A persons talents can really be utilized fully. It’s a fun, and loving environment. 
Very good 401K.
cons:
Administration seems to overlook the need to appreciate staff members. The majority of the times, staff members are overlooked in how the organization accomplishes its goals. Some admin simply don’t give thanks to the staff, and their actions as well say they are not thankful. 

Also, one thing that must change for this organization to be successful in reaching their goals and misson is the need of restructuring. For example, there is no Human Resources Director, I feel as if that alone is a huge part of why empolyee's are not valued. 

There is a rare occurrence of advancement within this organization. When there is an opportunity, they usually don’t promote individuals within the organization itself.

job_title: Youth Development Professional in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Staff are really invested in the kids especially when it comes to after school tutoring programs for the students. Depending on what facility you are at there is professional development training from outside consultants or psychologist that work with the staff with being able to empathize/sympathize with the students who may have parental/at home issues. Great organization for growth in company if they see that you are a hard worker, they like to hire inhouse staff who have been with them for years.
cons: For a while the org was taking a turn for the worse due to in house management but now with the recent management I have seen positive changes. Low pay for local staff. Wish they would invest in budget to provide professional growth for local staff in at risk areas since they have the most impact and influence on the kids.

job_title: Services to Clubs in Atlanta, GA
pros:
The work done by clubs is amazing. Not always innovative but the local clubs are a pilar and extension of many families and truly save the lives of so many kids. 
New national leadership seems to be of this century compared to the former CEO who truly let Rome burn while she did, well, something.
cons:
Massive silos, dysfunction 
No work life balance for some while others punch the clock. 
Pay is absurdly low for a national organization. The benefits are fair but do not offset the pay. 
Zero professional development for all but a few friends of HR. 
Some strong VP's but very few. Lack of RD leadership is clear. Strong director level and down but not up.

pros: Simple work. Decent environment. Easy money
cons: Over worked, rude coworkers last minute changes

review_title: Great place to make a difference in the world
pros: The people who work here are amazing. They really care about the work that we are doing and have strong relationships with kids and families. Management has increased training and support of staff and we do some fun things like a summer picnic, kickball tournament, and optional seminars are being offered about how to do your taxes or alternative medicine. Staff are recognized at different times in the year for good things they are doing.
cons: The work can be emotionally draining and when people leave the work gets harder but you always know your working with a team of people who really care.

review_title: Great Experience. Making a Big Impact
job_title: Sunmer Program Aid in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
I loved working at the BGC. You have no idea how much you mean to the kids until you go work here. Your experience with management really depends on your director. My unit director was really great because he provided a foundation on how to interact with the kids and he also knew when to step back and let me counsel my way. You have a lot of freedom to make your programming your own. AND THE KIDS LOVE YOU. 
The Boys & Girls Club is better than most youth programs because the counselors are engaged and get to know each child on a personal level. It's not just throw a bunch of kids in the gym and let them loose. Nope! You are playing with them!
cons: Hard to get ALL of the counselors motivated and to maintain good energy. The kids sense it and then the day doesn't go as well

pros: Important work that affects a wide community, very needed for low income families and for kids who are at risk.  In certain Clubs there is a great effort to work together for the benefit of the kids, but in others, there is partisan quibbling across the board.
cons: Low pay, spotty management practices, hard work, long hours.  Uneven evaluation practices, many of the long term employees are stuck without a career laddder, leading to a feeling of hopelessness that they will ever be promoted.  Financial management does not seem to be proactive.

pros: The best reason to work with the BGC is the kids. The kids that come there make my day because I know that I can help make a difference in their lives.
cons: Low pay. No type of recognition for all the work you do for the kids. The only people that get the recognition are the full time staff when they did not one thing. The company hire people that's not for the kids as well. The hiring process takes forever like the pay is that great. Also if you want to move up in the company, its not gonna happen unless you know somebody who knows somebody because they do not hire in house. They tend to look over part time staff that apply for full time positions. No benefits too.

pros: My time working as a site director for the Boys and Girls Club was a rewarding experience. Being a site director allows you to implement daily and weekly activies for elementary youth to flourish in a positive environment. It is also a job that develops your ability to stay patient, and adaptive. The kids view you as a positive role model, and you have the ability of making a difference in shaping their lives.
cons: The only cons of this job are the hours and the pay. This is a minimum wage job, with no real prospective raises. I did receive one raise, but it was not very substantial. This is a great job for recent high school and college grads. The hours were difficult. My schedule looked like this. 6:30-9:30am then 2-6:30PM, totalling under 40 hours a week. The split shitf was not for me but could be good for others

pros: You have the chance to Work with kids.
cons: Horrible Management, Horrible Employees, Unsafe for children, Unprofessional across the board, Communication, The way the discipline children.

pros:
I have been with the organization for 7 years and have truly enjoyed my time here.  The work pace is often hectic, but I have enjoyed the challenges and have grown my professional skills greatly.  You can't find a better group of people anywhere!!  

I find management to be more respectful of staff than in other places I've worked.  BGCA does try to help employees create a job/life balance.
cons: Being a non-profit, the salaries are not as high as in private industry.  BGCA does offer good benefits that helps off-set the difference.  With a new CEO in place, it will be interesting to see if the attitude toward 4 day work weeks and more telecommuting opportunites changes.

pros: About the only pro is the luke-warm feeling that you have done something positive in the life of a child. Even then, it's more of a consolation prize. Staying within licensing rules was a priority and was regularly achieved with minimal faults being recognized.
cons: There was a distinct lack of support from the management and almost a "setting you up to fail" system where it was impossible to succeed. I clearly recall several days where I was given my quota of children and expected to keep them all in line with the rules while still achieving objectives and having 0 support from any other staff. I was then held responsible when multiple fights broke out between children who were known to cause such issues and I was eventually let go for being a poor performer.

pros: I loved working with at risk students.  I really feel like I made a difference in their lives.  It is on paper a great program.
cons: It is beyond impossible to mentor and tutor a room of 50-125 students with a staff of only 4.  The upper management lies to the community, donors, and even state agencies about thier mentoring "at risk" students. Once again on paper it looks all fine and dandy, but in reality the centers are one event away from total chaos.  I do not know how the BGCA can get away with the staff to student ratio.  They also hire unqualified "babysitters" who are always on their cell phone or gossiping.  But then again they are paying almost minimum wage for a very serious job in my opinion.   I would really love for an independent investigator go in and see how the centers are "really run".

review_title: You better love kids, because they're the reason you keep coming back
pros: The kids. Hands down. As I mention in the cons, I struggle to only stay the allotted time I actually get paid and that's because you genuinely see the positive impact your work is doing. My bosses are phenomenal and very accommodating to days off or any flexibility they're able to provide in your schedule. I really enjoy my coworkers as well. It takes a certain kind of person to want to work with kids every day, needless to say we're all kind of big kids at heart who like to have fun too.
cons: Not enough hours, it's an after-school program for the majority of the year so you don't start working until the school day is over. That being said, I struggle to only work within the 2 1/2 hours I actually get paid everyday. I'm in there early inputting numbers and I stay late because I can't leave behind a child with a homework question.

job_title: STEM & Music Instructor in Jersey City, NJ
pros: The best part of the job is that you go into work every day knowing you're about to make a tangible positive impact on the world. The work it's self is interesting and exciting, and with the exception of fulfilling the occasional curriculum requirements of a given grant, I was allowed almost complete autonomy to create my own curriculum so long as my supervisor saw that I was hard at work. In general most people who elect to work with children are good at heart so the work environment is usually  positive.
cons: The administrative office is entirely out of touch with the teaching & childcare staff. There is virtually no communication and all the employees in the administrative office have a condescending notion of their own authority regardless of whether or not they actually your superior.

pros:
You are working for a great & noble cause and certainly feel great doing it!  Given the usual set of small staffing situations you will bond with your fellow staff and they will become your best of friends.  The BGCA Model is great and works well.  I'd send my kids there.

Great benefits, pension matching program, insurance, etc
cons:
As with working with youth entails, you are not here for the money.  Compensation is low and you will be working 50-60 hours a week on a salary scale.  You have no life outside of the club.  

Given the small compensation and low entry requirements you end up working with a lot of idiots to put it bluntly.  Certainly choose this career if you are ok with being let down by others that you depend on.

pros: Working with some awesome kids. Each day is different. Freedom to plan programs.
cons:
The various rules and procedures aren't taught yet you are expected to follow them.  Some of the older kids and teens greatly disliked "power hour" (designated hour to do homework or read). They would trick new staff into skipping it or shortening the time claiming previous staff did so. You get reprimanded for being fooled.

I was told I'd have a week with the director with me guiding and teaching me but it never happened. There were different rules for kids leaving the room for teen center than the rest of the club that I didn't know about. Pulled into coaching soccer when I've never played it in my life.

pros: Great hands on experience if you are going into a teaching or child development profession.  Set schedule of hours and weekends off.  Ability to maintain your own custom program, as long as it falls in line with corporate standards.  If you love working and  mentoring kids, it's a great job for you.
cons: No room for moving up the ladder unless you want to become a manager which opens up rarely.  Job description fluctuates and increases monthly to adhere to grant programs.  Managers rarely deal with employee competition or altercations between employees.  No pay increases or next to little to nothing.  No clear line of expectations between different sites and branches are penalized for not adhering to standards that were not established.

pros: If you truly want to have an impact on the lives of kids then the clubs may be a great place to work only if you solely interact with the kids.
cons: This organization is a sinking ship. Recently leadership changed and it has gotten worst. This organization I stealing grantors money and falsely reporting back to the grantors. When grants come into the organization for a specific purpose, the money disappears. Misappropriation of funds isn't the only problem, new leadership also plays a large role in the state of the organization. The new leader is not only inexperienced in his role but is also on a power trip. He is very unethical and contributes to the mismanagement of funds. Turnover continues to be high specifically in the finance department because managers lack people and management skills. The employees are overworked, underpaid and unappreciated. Do not work at or donate to this organization until there is new leadership.

review_title: My experience at this club has been horrible but working  with the kids could be a great opportunities all ages
pros: Very close to college and it looks good on your resume for education majors. Experience and location, pay isn't bad if your a college student, some managers are flexible with college students. Very easy job, field trips, cultural based events throughout the year
cons: Management is always bad. First boss that hired me. Was married with kids attending use to touch inappropriately on all female staff in addition My money will also be missing in almost every paycheck without me knowing, my second box here at the Boys and Girls Club showed favoritism to a few of the staff for an entire year buying them food and stuff for the club that they would not read ,salary needs to be higher for the kids we worked with, organization , too far from other clubs so you will lose opportunities and events the metro area clubs are having,

pros: The mission behind the Club, and what it does it solid. It's easy to fall in love with the kiddos and the mission of the organization
cons: The environment is political and petty. As the majority of the staff are all fairly young adults and this is their first job, it leads to a gossipy and juvenile work environment. The Executive Director chain smokes and the smell follows him everywhere. I watched him leer at his female staff, and then create toxic work environments until he pushed his unwanted staff to quit. He spends more time golfing with his buddies on the board, and working at his second business than running this organization and he's left the day to day operations to a girl barely out of college with no practical experience other than being bilingual.

pros: The children and the families=rewarding. Great learning experience on how "not to run a nonprofit".
cons:
You will be required to perform outside of your position day one.  This is great for an over-achiever but most management level employees have families of their own.  Expect to be recognized for your contributions if you can be creative(cost-efficient), but don't expect to be rewarded monetarily, even six months to a year after being employed.  You will be required to follow a variety of regulations including and not limited to SACC, DSS, etc.  You will often feel unprepared for these and will receive little to no support from administration.  High turnover rate.  Hiring process takes too long and you will be understaffed more than 75% of the time.  This of course is a SACC violation.  
Other cons- Not being a certified nurse/running out of band-aids.

job_title: Homework Tutor in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Very professional in the area that they specialize.
Very organized when ti comes to assisting youngins-teenagers
Extremely beneficial when it comes to influencing kids to go to college and to care more for their education and skills.
Emphasizes in teaching kids to look into their future and make something out of their lives.
cons: There are practically no cons, the objective of the Boys and Girls Club is to strengthen kids of all types, and ages character, and future skills. The only technical con is that if you are to become employed in this workforce, you must be dedicated to change lives for the better, be very social, and to enforce a work habit all around your work site. If you cannot do these things then you will not survive in this profession.

review_title: High energy and versatility is the best part of the job for me.
pros: Working with different ages of children is what we do.  To think that you could effect not only their day but, their future in how they feel about themselves is a great responsibility.  The teaching of coping and social skills is such a high need for today's children especially since so many live in two income families who have a limited amount of time with their children.  What we can do is so much more than "after school care" if the program is ran effectively.
cons: low quality employees teaching high self esteem

review_title: Rewarding, Challenging, and Life-long lessons learned.
pros:
The biggest "Pro" is the relationship with the kids. I enjoyed getting to know to them throughout my time there.

The managers and directors were incredibly nice people who genuinely wanted to provide a great place for the kids with learning and fun activities.
cons:
We weren't heavily trained. We mostly had to use applied skills from other areas of life and be able to use our common sense. 

Unstable structure- We had to work out the kinks as we went along. 

Kids are LOUD!

pros: The Boys and Girls Club gives a rewarding experience to work with kids of from k-12.  The kids grow on you.  Hands on, learn on the fly learning style. Well established company in the Inland  Empire. Memorable experience. Prepares people to learn how to budget
cons: Unclear expectation, unclear vision for the future. At times seemed no one really knew what future they had.  People wanted to stay but they just do not pay enough to keep good leaders round. Hiring Manager was disorganized, made promises she couldn't keep and often hired people who had no business working with people

review_title: CEO & Administrative Team treats lower employees like dirt.
pros: You get to work with kids, hopefully shaping their lives for the better.
cons: Almost too many to count. The biggest cons of working for the BGCA of Portland is that they completely destruct your dreams of helping kids by lowering salaries for their part time and full time employees while raising the salaries of the CEOs and other executives. I worked for three different BCGA centers, as well as 2 after school elementary schools, and the turnover of qualified people cycling through the clubs was completely disheartening and made the mission and the work ineffectual. The management is completely atrocious. The 2 best directors I worked with in my 3 years left because of dissatisfaction with the administration. AVOID THIS PLACE IF YOU CAN, THERE ARE BETTER PROGRAMS!!

pros:
This is corny but it really is rewarding to teach the children and to be their mentor. It can be easy work some days, too. If you have a well behaved group and you know how to handle the group, it's great. 
Four hours a day is convenient and the staff works with your dates of availability.
cons:
It can be tough working with large groups of children. At some site, the coordinator doesn't help in reinforcing rules. 

The Bakersfield branch is disorganized. The training dates were unclear and ultimately canceled. That untrained and clueless staff. 
As a side note, the HR lady is terrible at emailing back on whether my time off request was received or not. As a college student, I would appreciate knowing that I can take a final without reprisals from work but apparently that's too much to ask.

review_title: Old-fashioned, married to the past and full of cronyism
pros: Mission.  The mission to serve youth most in need is wonderful and there are many good clubs across the country executing on the mission well.  The kids are wonderful but you are removed from them by working at headquarters.
cons:
Long-term employees with "that's not how we do it here" mentality.
Top performances not valued.  Only old relationships valued.
Pay - below average for job and market
Cronyism.  Some old, blind allegiances in too many key departments or individuals who are under-qualified yet yell discrimination and end up protected. Some leaders need to go.  Others who are newer are a mixed bag.  Understand that a staffer from Komen was hired and is now bringing in tons of Komen people without having to post jobs or allow others to apply.  Is that what Boys & Girls Clubs needs?  Another Komen, political nightmare?

pros: Co workers in other departments are amazing! Benefits ok pay ok... the kids were the most important part.
cons: Upper management is terrible. Hard to believe both HR and senior management haven't caught on that they are losing a lot of new talent to keep higher level employees that are bad at thier job. Turn over happens for a reason! If a department or specific manager keeps losing people THERE IS A REASON! and it's not because all the people that left were bad at thier job... Foundation relations is terribly run and the manager of that team is hands down terrible. Hoping senior leadership will wake up and realize who the real problem is.

review_title: The kids are worth every other problem that arises
job_title: Program Assistant in Southern Pines, NC
pros: The kids! Sure, every time you work with kids you will have the ones that sometimes feel like a lost cause but none of them are, they are all truly worth every stressful moment. The kids are amazing! The coworkers are great too, such a family.
cons: The management is very hard to deal with, while they are trying to help you grow they do it in a way that you feel put down.

job_title: After School Program Staff in Atlanta, GA
pros: If you truly like working with kids, then you have the flexibility of creating your own programming (with certain limitation) one on one interaction, and ample opportunity to mentor
cons: If you are not used to this kind of setting, it may be too much. Instructor to youth ratios are high (1 to 30+), discipline styles can be "mom & pop" type of stuff, so locations don't hold parents or students responsible for their actions, staff morale at some sites are low

pros: The people working on the ground put in an exorbitant amount of effort, especially for so little money and so little recognition. They really care about their kids and their work.
cons: The Philadelphia BGCs are headed by an administrative with an agenda. They are making big money off of the organization and give the bare minimum to the actual clubs. They offer no raises, no team building, no employee recognition except for once a year when you get a pat on the back if you sell a lot of gift baskets for their fundraiser.  At my site, the kids' bathrooms were broken for an entire summer, during which the boys and girls had to share one bathroom with only two stalls, for 75 kids.  Administration picked and chose which sites got materials and supplies and which didn't. They are completely unsupportive of staff and rarely bother to leave Center City headquarters to visit the kids. And Libby Lescalleet is an evil witch.

review_title: Working with kids is the most rewarding!
pros: Working with the kids, part time hours, field trips are always fun in the summer! You have opportunities to move up with education and experience but the higher you go the less you engage with the students.
cons: Politics from people that work in offices and cubicles can make you want to quit because they think they know what the kids are going through and need but they're really concerned about making themselves look good. They make you work overtime and don't compensate you. Very sneaky organization. They wany you to be a  teacher but won't pay you like one!

review_title: It is what you make of it.  Find the good and use it to get through your time there.
pros: You will have an opportunity to connect with many people within the organization.  The mission to develop underserved youth is an admirable endeavor.  You will feel rewarded knowing that you are a part of such an important initiative.  It has a very strong connection in regards to representation nationwide including celebrity support.
cons: The salaries are less than desirable in my opinion.  I also think there is a disproportion in pay for the same positions among employees.  Preferential treatment among some circles of leadership and limited growth opportunities.  There is a disproportion of diversity in leadership positions.  Rural Clubs are not as well supported as metropolitan Clubs  You have to drink the Kool-Aid!

pros: Awesome opportunity to give back and help develop character and strength in our future leaders. The club is set up to help provide a positive experience for members 6-18. As staff you get to shape and pour into children who may not have a lot of positive environments at the time. A lot is asked of you but you get to be creative and have fun while loving on some "lovable" kids too !!! Impacting lives for the better everyday .....
cons: Pay is not great and there are minimal benefits. A lot to do in certain positions e.g. Art room, learning center.....Limited hours that will be paid. Limited full-time opportunities too.

pros: Caring coworkers, fulfilling work, great benefits package with sick days, a lot of vacation - holidays and 2 weeks off at the end of August, good insurance. Lots of young employees, great place to get your feet wet with youth work. Huge amount of continuing education.
cons: Working with at risk youth day in and day out can be draining, some of the employees and supervisors haven't ever worked outside of the clubs so it can get kind of cliquish. Management isn't always on the floor and aware of club dynamics and employee needs nor are they always apt to listen. Hours are tough, 1pm-8:30pm at some clubs.

review_title: Mission and goals are lost on senior management.
pros: In theory this should be one of the most rewarding jobs there is.  Knowing that I am helping children who need it the most and who would otherwise be playing on the streets is what keep me going.  The Anaheim business community is very supportive and long-standing residents are wonderful and passionate to work with.
cons: Management is the common thread for employee/community/donor dissatisfaction.  Not having any experience or education in the business world really holds the organization back.  There is a lack on infrastructure in place that is needed for this organization to reach the capacity that I should have.  The potential for greatness at the organization is being held back because of a lack of vision and planning.

job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Naples, FL
pros: Our organization strives to make a difference in the lives of the children we serve. They’re many intricate roles to any organization, the key is finding a role that pairs you with your passion. The organization provides advancement opportunity, professional development, and great benefits.  Best of all the opportunity to join a transitioning team making a difference in our community.
cons: The organization is going through a transitional phase that has unfortunately been misrepresented by subjective feedback.   The struggle with any company is managing its cyclical turnover, without it, companies may be slower to evolve.

review_title: Underpaid for the Level of Chaos
pros: Its fun to work with the kids, you have a lot of leeway as to what you can do with them (i.e. teach them little art projects, play games, etc.)
cons:
The children can be a lot to handle, and there isn't much you can do to discipline them beyond scolding or write-ups (which don't always do anything).

Its a very hectic environment and lots of times its only you and 10-15 other children, and when your back is turned and something happens, you're still responsible for that (even though kids will get into anything and everything when you aren't able to keep an eye on them).

pros: The people here care about children. They will work hard for a child... provided they have a connection with that child. They have locations all over Pasco and will soon get to move to other cities maybe. Their pre-school program is well set up and run.
cons: The staff are very click-ish with each other and excusatory. If you don't make friends fast you will be pushed out. They will make fun of children, parents and each other if they do not like them. There are almost no programs for kids over elementary school to engage in. The administration severely suffers from doing only what it wants, your opinions may be asked for but do not let that fool you into believing you can at all be honest. If you say anything negative, to anyone you will be black listed.

review_title: If you love kids and making a difference in their lives, then this is the place to work!
pros: Working as a Director at multiple after school programs and summer camps was extremely rewarding.  Some of the kids in the program really need positive mentors.  I saw very positive results in many of the children that had difficulties at home, school, etc.
cons: Sometimes BGCA hires staff employees that are too young or immature to meet the emotional needs that some of these children have.  These employees often gossip and cause a disruptive environment instead of focusing on the safety and well being of the kids.

pros: The people who relate to the struggle are great-- made the best friends of my life chugging along, trying to get through each day.  the number of kids they serve each day is incredible.
cons: Within 1 month of being there I knew not only was BGCMA making unethical moves across fundraising, club choices, and much more, but they treated employees like they were lucky to work there, instead of being proud of the accomplishments employees were making for kids.  There was no SOP (standard operating procedure) to anything that was done, and while I personally liked the CEO, she was extremely re-active when situations went poorly and never pro-active, even when staff were pointing out the issue.

review_title: Negative review of working at boys and girls club of Lawrence
pros: If you are interested in pursuing a degree in education, this is a good place to work while you are in college.
cons: I have had a very negative experience here. The pay is low. In my experience, directors do not respect the group leaders' decisions, who are in charge of leading kids through activities. The policy of giving discipline sheets and suspension is never followed through on part of the directors. I've had kids call me all types of curse words, throw things at me, yell, get in fights with other kids, yet when I tell my director, the kids do not get in trouble. This allows bad behavior to continue. I feel like our directors care more about keeping parents happy instead of following through with rules. I'm very disappointed with this organization.

pros: Working for the Boys & Girls Club is very rewarding. You invest your time and passion into youth that need it most. Seeing them grow and be successful is one of the biggest pay offs and truly self rewarding and adds self value.
cons: At the particular location I was at in Whittier, CA there wasn't much room for growth. There was this unspoken rule of keeping all positions part-time right under ACA benefit regulations in order to not provide benefits to their workers, only problem is that a lot of positions require more hours to complete the daily tasks, and execute the job duties correctly and efficiently.

job_title: Development Associate in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The thought that you are helping children achieve their goals in life and providing them with an opportunity to learn in a safe and clean environment.
cons: Quick to let people go despite not giving them proper training and lying about job descriptions prior to hiring them.

pros: Great place to work with a great set of kids.
cons: Management sometimes took advantage of me because I always did everything they asked.  I love helping out in every way possible, but when I am doing the work that other employees should be doing, it gets frustrating. Also, about a month before I left the company they hired  a friend group that constantly goofed off, rarely interacted with the kids, and pretty much just used the pool table in the games room for their own pleasure instead of letting the kids play.

pros: Kids are amazing I love all of my members. They are the sole reason I haven’t quit. I fight everyday to be there for them.
cons: Inconsistent in discipline, poor communication, extremely disorganized. There are too many people who don’t care at all in high positions. They are there for a paycheck not the kids. They will let their employees drown. Staff can be disrespected and mistreated (even threatened) by parents and kids and site coordinators and managers do not care. People who actually care are being broken down by the distinction. No one can survive in an environment like this. This is an organization wide issue not just one location. So many people have begged for change and been ignored and or pushed to the point of leaving. It’s unfair to the kids. It goes against everything the organization “says” they stand for. I’ve reached my limit and I’m not alone.

pros:
Always in need of help/there is a place for everyone.
Often open to ideas for activities and filed trips.
Morally fulfilling work; you know that what you are doing is good for the community.
cons:
Many positions are part-time, even if they have titles (mine was Teen Specialist).  As such, there is every possibility that taking a leave of absence for even a couple months will result in the position being filled.

I was also unhappy with the lack of follow-through on discipline sometimes.  Not all staff members were on the same page regarding discipline which resulted in a disjointed and fractured staff relationship.

review_title: Enjoyed working with the kids and fellow staff, but upper management was just not connected with the day to day.
job_title: Group Leader in Kansas City, MO
pros: You really get great opportunities to change kids' lives.
cons: It's all about 'programming' and it really doesn't matter if it's done, the paperwork just has to be done. It would be great to interact more with donors and allow donors to actually see the kids. It would also be great to have some input in programming and allow the kids to rate their experience.

job_title: After School Teacher in Seattle, WA
pros: I loved working here. The hours were great for part time (weekdays 2-6pm) and the kids were really fun. There were free snacks and the director bought us lunch during the staff meeting about one a month. You got to know a lot of cool kids, go on a few field trips, and play games all the time.
cons: Not the best pay, work with a lot of young and inexperienced staff, high turnover. But that's to be expected with part time work like this. I left once I found a full time job.

review_title: Program Specialist and Program Assistant Sub
pros:
-Fun staff
-Paid trainings
-Work study programs
-Somewhat flexible schedule(no early mornings or late nights)
-Non-profit organization so there are no sales goals, quotas, commissions, etc.
cons:
-Can get easily terminated or demoted based on opinions (hear-say,gossip,grapevines,lies) not facts. 
-Do not expect to get trained your first week on the job. I got trained a year after I started working there and I was completely clueless!
-Little pay and staff could only work for 4 hours per day. Upper management, like campus director's got the most hours at the highest hourly pay.
-No full-time positions, all part-time unless campus director or higher.
-Some of the kids are sweet but the majority do not care about respecting you as an adult.
-Training day is on Saturday!

review_title: Depends on your location and the manater
pros: The kids are wonderful of course. If you have good managers, you'll have a relatively good experience.
cons: Experience varies wildly depending on which club you work at and who manages there. At times my location was a dysfunctional and toxic workplace, and other times it was fine, depending on management changes. Since my club was in a poor area the staff was paid less than staff at other locations and we were constantly understaffed, underfunded, lacking in supplies, had poor facilities, etc. Meanwhile kids in clubs in wealthier areas had everything they needed.

review_title: In need of some major re-working
pros: Very rewarding, weekends off, get the chance to build great relationships with children and staff
cons: Upper management out of touch with the kids and needs of the staff.  Organization is financially insecure, expected to meet goals and expectation with little to no budget.  Upper management plays favorites.  The CEO is super shady and runs the organization like a "Boys Club."  For an organization that could do so much good, they fall short due to red tape, politics and a lack of priorities.

review_title: An enjoyable way to make a difference.
pros: The facilities which house The Boys & Girls Club of Brattleboro are absolutely wonderful, eclectic, and just plain fun. This in turn makes it a great place to mentor youth. The staff are always well-selected and a joy to work with. There is a freedom to share one's passions in a unique way which is generally supported.
cons: Things appear to be run on a shoe-string budget due to it being challenging to source funding. This doesn't have much of an impact on the overall quality of the club, however, due to the ingenuity of the staff.

review_title: Good Environment but with Stifled Grouth
pros:
The environment is highly engaging and sometimes very fun.
Your choice of activities to engage in, such as various sports and table games. The kids bring a lot of positive energy. I think working at "the club" is more beneficial to high school or college age employees.
cons: It's really a road to nowhere. There's little in the way of progressing your career here. Often times, new employees with less work experience will get hired on alongside seasoned vets and get paid more as a result. This type of work environment often leads to a very high employee turn-over ratio. It's like a revolving door. For those looking to start a career, it can be difficult to move up the corporate ladder.

review_title: Chew you up, spit you out
pros: Some nice people, relationship with the kids, fun to work in active environment, always busy
cons: Treats staff like dirt, lack of experienced management, false data reporting, selfish and full of lies CEO, board knows nothing but what's fed to them by CEO and make no effort to investigate staff accusations, kids do whatever they want there is no supervision, high school/early college are supervising their peers, HIGH turnover, building falling apart because instead they spend money to pay celebrities $250,000+ to attend events,
